pageContext.name: RdCv5n6p13-notes
pageContext.prefixed:
<tei-noteGrp data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="RdCv2n1-notes" id="RdCv2n1-notes" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id xmlns">
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="mock1" id="mock1" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">The following article on Olaudah Equiano, also known as Gustavus Vassa, is excerpted from Abbé Grégoire’s <tei-title data-origname="title">De la littérature des nègres</tei-title> (1808). The abolitionist Grégoire presents the literary work of Black writers as evidence of their equal claim to humanity and human rights.</tei-p>
      <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">
        Dorigny, Marcel. <tei-title data-origname="title">Les Abolitions de l'esclavage (1793-1888)</tei-title>. Presses universitaires de France, 2008.
      </tei-bibl>
      <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Sepinwall, Alyssa Goldstein. <tei-title data-origname="title">The Abbé Grégoire and the French Revolution: The Making of Modern Universalism</tei-title>. University of California Press, 2005.</tei-bibl>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">The following article on Olaudah Equiano, also known as Gustavus Vassa, is excerpted from Abbé Grégoire’s <tei-title data-origname="title">De la littérature des nègres</tei-title> (1808). The abolitionist Grégoire presents the literary work of Black writers as evidence of their equal claim to humanity and human rights.</tei-p>
      <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">
        Dorigny, Marcel. <tei-title data-origname="title">Les Abolitions de l'esclavage (1793-1888)</tei-title>. Presses universitaires de France, 2008.
      </tei-bibl>
      <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Sepinwall, Alyssa Goldstein. <tei-title data-origname="title">The Abbé Grégoire and the French Revolution: The Making of Modern Universalism</tei-title>. University of California Press, 2005.</tei-bibl>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="mock2" id="mock2" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Equiano claims to have been born in the Kingdom of Benin, not to be confused with the current nation of Benin. Abbé Grégoire uses the same spelling as Equiano, so there appears to have been a transcription error on the part of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Equiano claims to have been born in the Kingdom of Benin, not to be confused with the current nation of Benin. Abbé Grégoire uses the same spelling as Equiano, so there appears to have been a transcription error on the part of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>.</tei-p>    
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="mock3" id="mock3" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">The <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue Coloniale</tei-title>, was an ephemeral monthly periodical, printed in Paris during the year 1838. Its founder Édouard Bouvet and editor Rosemond Beauvallon conceived of it on the model of many similar, contemporaneous publications reporting on political and economic questions of interest to white colonists while also attending to arts and literature, as attested by the journal’s complete title: <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue Coloniale. intérêts des colons : marine, commerce, littérature, beaux-arts, théâtres, modes</tei-title>. In the December 1838 issue of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title>, Cyrille Bissette acknowledges the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue Coloniale</tei-title> as both an ideological adversary and an opponent.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">The <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue Coloniale</tei-title>, was an ephemeral monthly periodical, printed in Paris during the year 1838. Its founder Édouard Bouvet and editor Rosemond Beauvallon conceived of it on the model of many similar, contemporaneous publications reporting on political and economic questions of interest to white colonists while also attending to arts and literature, as attested by the journal’s complete title: <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue Coloniale. intérêts des colons : marine, commerce, littérature, beaux-arts, théâtres, modes</tei-title>. In the December 1838 issue of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title>, Cyrille Bissette acknowledges the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue Coloniale</tei-title> as both an ideological adversary and an opponent.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
</tei-noteGrp>
